stem: The nurse is analyzing pediatric congenital heart defects. For each defect, select whether it primarily results in Cyanotic (decreased pulmonary blood flow/mixing) or Acyanotic (increased pulmonary blood flow/obstruction) clinical presentations.

rows.text: Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) or Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD).

rationale.correct: Defects are categorized by their effect on oxygenation. (r1 & r3) ASD, VSD, and PDA are 'Left-to-Right' shunts; blood is re-circulated to the lungs (Acyanotic). (r2 & r4) Tetralogy and Transposition involve deoxygenated blood entering the systemic circulation directly (Cyanotic).
rationale.incorrect: Coarctation of the Aorta is also acyanotic but involves obstruction of flow rather than a shunt.
clinicalPearls: Infants with Tetralogy of Fallot may experience 'Tet spells' during crying or feeding, which are managed by placing the child in a knee-chest position.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that defects starting with 'T' (Tetralogy, Transposition, Tricuspid Atresia, Truncus Arteriosus) are generally the CYANOTIC ones. 'T' = Blue/Trouble.

mnemonic.title: A-v-B
mnemonic.expansion: Acyanotic (ASD, VSD, PDA - pink/congested), Blue (Tetralogy, Transposition - cyanotic).

reviewUnits.heading: Congenital Heart Defects
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for growth failure, respiratory distress, and clubbing. Treatment varies from 'watchful waiting' (VSD) to emergency surgical repair (Transposition).
